West Virginia Flood Donations – A List of 10 Ways To Help

Many people are wanting to help West Virginia flood victims, but there is so much information being given that decisions are difficult. Hopefully, this list will help a little. 1. Snowshoe Foundation: Our thoughts are with everyone affected by the recent severe weather and storms. Partnering with Snowshoe Mountain, we have set up a donation portal to anyone who would like to contribute to the communities of the Mountain State to help rebuild what was lost. We’ve started the ball rolling with a $10k contribution. We’ll be accepting donations through July 8, 2016. At that time, we’ll make a lump donation to the American Red Cross of West Virginia. The donations will be directly used to help rebuild and support our local communities. Thank you for any support large or small. For more information, please click on the link below: https://snowshoefoundation.org/ 2. West Virginia Flood Relief – a gofundme account set up by Brad Paisley. https://www.gofundme.com/WestVirginiaFloods On June 23rd, my home state of West Virginia experienced tremendous flooding that killed over 20 people and destroyed entire small towns. Three counties have been declared federal disasters and 44 of the 55 counties have been declared in a state of emergency. Now that the waters are receding it's time to pitch in and help in any way we can. One of the best ways I have found that hopefully will raise the largest amount of money the quickest and get it to the people in need the fastest is through GoFundMe. I have set a goal of $1 million -- this is doable and only a small portion of what is needed. All funds donated will be distributed through West Virginia Flood Relief 2016 - The Brad Paisley Foundation at WESBANCO Trust Department in Wheeling, WV. Join me as we help West Virginians together. Help spread the word! 3. Pro golfer Bubba Watson, who has a summer home near the Greenbrier Resort, pledged to donate at least $250,000 to relief and recovery. The annual Greenbrier Classic has been cancelled due to flooding, however, the PGA Tour is making a $100,000 donation to the American Red Cross to help people affected by the floods. Fans wishing to assist in the relief and recovery efforts can do so by making donations at http://pgatour.com/together. Starting on June 28, all donations will be distributed to American Red Cross West Virginia Flood Relief. - information courtesy of – Adam Schupak of Golfweek. 4. Florida Relief Effort for West Virginia https://www.facebook.com/floridareliefeffortforwestvirginia/ “…As the clean up begins, the needs are rising. We created this page to get the word out that we are standing with you and are here to help. Please consider stopping by one of our donation drop off locations (locations to be posted shortly) with your donation…” 5. From WV Living Magazine - Flood Relief Resources Published June 29, 2016 http://www.wvliving.com/Summer-2016/Flood-Relief-Resources/ In response to the devastating floods in West Virginia, many are asking how they can help their neighboring counties and communities recover. Our goal is to provide you with a variety of resources to volunteer and donate to the relief effort. Statewide resources -Visit http://www.redcross.org/mo2 , call 1.800.RED.CROSS, or text “WV FLOODS” to 90999 to make a $10 donation to the Red Cross. -Save The Children is taking donations to provide relief and support for West Virginia's children at https://secure.savethechildren.org/site/c.8rKLIXMGIpI4E/b.9419583/k.F41/West_Virginia_Floods_Childrens_Relief_Fund/apps/ka/sd/donor.asp?msource=wexggwvf0616&gclid=CM__sr__yM0CFceCfgodQJUAtw . Note: Actress Jennifer Garner, from Charleston, is a trustee of Save The Children and is encouraging donations for affected children. http://wchstv.com/news/local/jennifer-garner-urges-support-for-west-virginia-kids-in-flood-aftermath -Sign up with Volunteer West Virginia at www.volunteerwv.org to find volunteer opportunities. -Numerous drop-off locations have been set up throughout the state. Find a drop-off location near you: http://www.wsaz.com/content/news/Drop-off-locations-in-Huntington-Barboursville-for-flood-victims-384306181.html. Resources in affected communities Cabell County The City of Huntington and the Ohio Valley Environmental Coalition (OVEC) have established drop-off locations for supplies that will be distributed to flood victims in West Virginia. For more information, visit http://wvcag.org/wv-flood-donation-locations/. Greenbrier County For immediate monetary support via United Way of Greenbrier Valley, visit unitedwaygreenbrier.org/flood. For long-term recovery monetary support via Greenbrier Valley Community Foundation, visit www.gvfoundation.org or email [email protected]. Harrison County The Bridgeport Fire Department on West Main Street, the Shinnston Volunteer Fire Department, the Lumberport Volunteer Fire Department, the Spelter Volunteer Fire Department, and the Stonewood Volunteer Fire Department are collecting items. For more on items requested, visit http://wvcag.org/wv-flood-donation-locations/. Lewis County Donations can be made at Pricetown Volunteer Fire Department, 8 a.m. through 8 p.m. all week, and at Weston Walmart, 11 a.m. through 8 p.m. all week. Mercer & Monroe counties: Contact the Community Foundation of the Virginias at 304.324.0222 or email [email protected] for more information. Nicholas County Donate online at http://www.razoo.com/us/story/Nccfwv?referral_code=share . This fundraiser is being managed by The Nicholas County Community Foundation. Donations can be earmarked to help with specific areas or needs. If you don't want to donate electronically, you can mail a check to: Nicholas County Community Foundation, PO Box 561, Summersville, WV 26651. You can also sign up to volunteer in Richwood at http://rebuildrichwood.com/volunteer/. Raleigh County Contact the Beckley Area Foundation at 304.253.3806 or email [email protected]. For more information, visit bafwv.org. Summers County Contact the Hinton Area Foundation at 304.466.5332 or email [email protected] or [email protected]. Barbour, Boone, Clay, Fayette, Kanawha, and Roane counties: Donate online at http://wvcag.org. Contact the Greater Kanawha Valley Foundation at 304.346.3620 or email [email protected] for information on donating and volunteering. 6. FACEBOOK SAFETY CHECK - The Flooding in West Virginia https://www.facebook.com/safetycheck/westvirginia-flood-jun25-2016/ Mark Yourself Safe Let your friends know you're OK by marking yourself safe. They'll be notified if you do. Check on Friends Quickly find and connect with friends in the area. Mark them safe if you know they're OK. 7. From/by Brooke Thibodaux, WCHS/WVAH Eyewitness News: “Stuffed animal donations help brighten day of kids staying at Capital High School shelter.” http://wchstv.com/news/local/stuffed-animal-donations-help-brighten-day-of-kids-staying-at-capital-high-school-shelter J.R. Bailey and Sandy James bought $500 worth of stuffed animals, and passed out some of them to children at Capital High School—where several flood-displaced families are staying. Estimates are they $4000 more to pass them out to all affected children. Bailey explained why he thinks something seemingly so simple can help. "Stuffed animals. How would that help? And then I thought, 'Yeah, that's what they sleep with. They're devastated. They're sleeping in a strange bed in a strange place with a lot of strange people around." If this is a way you would like to help, you may drop off stuffed animals at First Baptist Church in Dunbar. To coordinate donation, call 1-304-768-1822 or 1-304-542-7418. The church is open 8:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. Monday through Friday. 8. WCHS TV, WVAH TV to air statewide telethon for West Virginia flood relief efforts By Jeffrey Morris Thursday, June 30, 2016 The "Rebuild West Virginia" telethon was broadcast 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. and streamed live at www.wchstv.com. Proceeds will go directly to American Red Cross relief efforts across the Mountain State. Contributions are being accepted until 10:00 p.m. EDT. Telethon viewers will be asked to make donations directly to flood relief efforts at www.rebuildwestvirginia.com and to text the word "WVFLOODS" to 90999 to make a $10 donation, or to call 877-273-0511 during the telethon. 9. West Virginia Floods Lost and Found Pets – Ndarrt https://www.facebook.com/NDARRT/ The National Disaster Animal Response and Recovery Teams is a national non-profit organization that helps reunite animals with their owners. 10. The Kanawha-Charleston Humane Association has pets found in the flooding for adoption, always needs monetary donations and may still need dog food donations. Contact them at http://adoptcharleston.com/give.
